properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, blowing snow and strong northwesterly winds are expected. Further snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 120 km/h. Locations: Hopedale to Makkovik. Time span: continuing until early Sunday. Remarks: Snow will combine with strong northwesterly winds today to cause poor visibility in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve in Hopedale this evening and in Postville and Makkovik by Sunday morning as the snow tapers to flurries and the winds begin to ease. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-17T01:28:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-16T09:29:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2013037457.2019
Area: Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, blowing snow and strong northwesterly winds are expected. Further snowfall: 5 cm near Nain to 20 cm near Natuashish. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h except 100 along parts of the coast. Time span: continuing until early this evening. Remarks: Snow will continue to combine with strong northwesterly winds to cause poor visibility in blowing snow. Stormy conditions will then persist through today, especially in the Natuashish area. Conditions will improve by this evening over all locations as the snow tapers to flurries and the winds begin to ease. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-17T01:28:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-16T09:29:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2697618596.2019
Area: Nain and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wet weekend for Metro Vancouver Heavy rain is in store for Metro Vancouver this weekend. An atmospheric river will take aim at Vancouver Island beginning early this morning delivering heavy rain and mild conditions until mid-day Sunday. The heaviest rainfall is expected to be near northshore where 40 to 50 mm are possible by Sunday morning. Given the tropical origin of the atmospheric river, freezing levels will be on the rise upwards of 3000 metres for the South Coast. The mild air will result in rain at almost all elevations. High runoff and rising river levels are likely through the weekend. The public is encouraged to monitor rainfall and wind warnings from Environment and Climate Change Canada as well as potential high streamflow advisories or flood watches from the BC River Forecast Centre. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T04:48:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-16T12:49:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3778147542.2019
Area: Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High levels of pollutants are expected to persist until late this morning in this region. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-11-16T21:59:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2019-11-16T09:24:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3363819762.2019
Area: La Sarre area, Amos area, Lebel-sur-Quévillon area, Senneterre area, Rouyn area, Malartic area, Val d'Or - Louvicourt area
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system will track up the American Eastern Seaboard on Sunday and Monday, bringing a mixed bag of precipitation over Southern Quebec. They are expected to begin as freezing rain Monday afternoon or Monday evening before changing over to snow overnight. Freezing precipitation amounts could be significant over several areas Monday and make roads and other surfaces very slippery. The exact track of this system remains uncertain, which may influence areas at risk. Further details will be provided in future forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T02:17:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-16T10:18:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4048221027.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Persistent snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T06:57:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-16T14:57:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0335268399.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rain is expected for the inland sections of the north and central coasts, the Sunshine Coast and Howe Sound. An atmospheric river will take aim at North Vancouver Island and the Central Coast beginning early this morning delivering heavy rain and mild conditions until mid-day Sunday. Rainfall amounts of 50 to 70 mm are expected by Sunday morning for the aforementioned regions. Given the tropical origin of the atmospheric river, freezing levels will be on the rise upwards of 3000 metres for the South Coast and close to 2500 metres for the North Coast. The mild air will result in rain at almost all elevations. High runoff and rising river levels are likely through the weekend. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T04:51:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-16T12:52:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1456958657.2019
Area: Central Coast - inland sections, Sunshine Coast - Gibsons to Earls Cove, Sunshine Coast - Saltery Bay to Powell River, Howe Sound, North Coast - inland including Kitimat

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: 100 km/h. Locations: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity. Time span: this afternoon and evening. Remarks: A period of strong northwesterly winds is expected to develop later today, with the highest gusts likely to occur along exposed areas of the coast. Winds will gradually subside overnight and into Sunday. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A vigorous frontal system is approaching Haida Gwaii this morning. Southeast winds of 80 km/h will increase to 90 km/h gusting to 110 early this morning. The winds will become southwesterly and ease near noon. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T01:59:35-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. An area of high pressure entrenched over the Mackenzie basin will combine with an approaching low over the Gulf of Alaska will produce strong winds and blizzard conditions to the Dempster highway. Winds up to 110 km/h and falling snow will produce blizzard conditions near the Richardson mountains. The blizzard will begin overnight Saturday. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T04:34:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-16T12:35:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2612946773.2019
Area: Dempster

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. An area of freezing rain is tracking through east central Alberta and northwestern Saskatchewan. This area is expected to continue to track eastward overnight tonight and move out of the area after midnight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-16T17:29:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-16T06:21:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3414567755.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant high-elevation snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: near 5 cm, except 15 to 25 cm over higher terrain. Time span: continuing into tonight. Locations: Bay St. George to Hawke's Bay. Remarks: Flurries will persist today with possible snow squalls, before gradually easing tonight. Anyone using the Viking Trail through Gros Morne National Park or high-elevation backcountry trails should be prepared for winter travel conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-17T04:59:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-16T14:29:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1415567448.2019
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard tonight and Sunday. An intense low pressure system is forecast to develop in Foxe Basin tonight. Strong northerly winds will rapidly develop at Naujaat this evening, with potential gusts to 90 km/h starting in the overnight hours. Blizzard conditions in snow and blowing snow will accompany the strong winds and last through Sunday. Visibilities will begin to improve late Sunday evening as the winds diminish. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T01:19:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-16T09:20:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4103272927.2019
Area: Naujaat
properties.Author: Environment Canada
